data.title: Metalcore Milestones
data.text:
Dwid says I coined the term ‚Äúmetalcore.‚Äù

I say his band, Integrity, invented the genre.

I‚Äôm not talking about metallic hardcore bands, punky metal acts, or the distinct ‚Äúcrossover‚Äù sub-genre. Metalcore began with a very specific style of guitars, breakdowns, vocals, and subject matter.

And it evolves.

Nearly every artist on earth is uncomfortable with genre tags or the other artists they are often associated with, and certainly, metalcore is crowded and ever more loosely defined. But it‚Äôs all undeniably connected.

Think about the last time you recommended a movie, TV series, or book to someone. Undoubtedly, you made some comparisons, you mentioned a genre or two, and it didn‚Äôt mean you were limiting the artistic expression.

It wasn‚Äôt easy to narrow it down to a single metalcore record for each year since the genre began in earnest, but I got it done. üòé

These are the most influential metalcore records by year.

Integrity Those Who Fear Tomorrow

(Overkill Records) 1991

Always Is Always Forever DVD.

Starkweather Crossbearer

(Harvest Records) 1992

CBGB‚Äôs, New York, NY, 1992.

(Victory Records) 1993

Lost Horizon, Syracuse, NY, 1993.

(New Age Records) 1994

World Beat Center, San Diego, CA, 1994.

Washington, D.C., 1995.
